## Introduction

In construction!!

The extent and dynamics of wetlands in a region should be also modelled and included in further assessments.

For instance, the Wetland Area and Dynamics for Methane Modeling (WAD2M, [Zhang et al. 2021](https://essd.copernicus.org/articles/13/2001/2021/)), the Satellite-Derived Global Surface Water Extent and Dynamics (GIEMS-2, [Prigent et al. 2019](https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1029/2019JD030711)),  the TOPMODEL has been used to model spatiotemporal dynamics of global wetlands ([Zhang et al. 2016](https://bg.copernicus.org/articles/13/1387/2016/bg-13-1387-2016.pdf)), and the Dynamical Peatland Model Based on TOPMODEL (DYPTOP) in combination with  [LPX-Bern](https://www.climate.unibe.ch/research/research_groups/earth_system_modelling_biogeochemical_cycles/lpx/index_eng.html) DGVM are used to "benchmark the global-scale distribution, extent, and seasonality of inundation against satellite data" ([Stocker et al. 2014](https://gmd.copernicus.org/articles/7/3089/2014/gmd-7-3089-2014.pdf)).

"Simulating the spatio-temporal dynamics of inundation is key to understanding the role of wetlands under past and future climate change" ([Stocker et al. 2014](https://gmd.copernicus.org/articles/7/3089/2014/gmd-7-3089-2014.pdf)). Wetlands can be modeled as single units or embedded in a watershed and/or instream model. [Mozafari et al. (2023)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0048969723015061) provided a comprehensive review of process-based models and approaches to model wetlands dynamic, highlighting those with peatlands modules.

Others have used open source and high resolution data, and convolutional networks models to map local wetlands at 1 meter spatial resolution ([Mainali et al. 2023](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0048969722077257)).

Tracking global change in wetlands extent, assessment and conservation status have been implemented. For instance,  the Wetland Extent Trend index developed by [Dixon et al. (2016)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0006320715301476) (not well documented), the evaluation of wetland loss at coarse spatial resolution over the past three centuries shows that the HJBL is practically intact ([Fluet-Choiunard et al. 2023](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-022-05572-6.epdf?sharing_token=T_gy2x7t3BcIVNW7LADNItRgN0jAjWel9jnR3ZoTv0PbHROEZ7UgcrLuGBROGGb5myeKrDMguIKVy0wCrjzHBxfEZYpCWx4muajTIuHlInrwffm5Y023LgLLhvePPHgTCOO2B9Qt_6C6Gq-91rlsFFAjl4qkSzz2YwOV4FheYH0FW63SVw9p6WR9QByOu5gbRuEprF1v1f5FNTr2CfETzvYsWwXWLAi8Z08IzSCLvAol0HGRHE1BUmefqTpn_ZtQoi0q_g_65ajKmPNUivmU0ttKMaGL1aBnU9RNq2rr84kCG9wSXiv-0aAimeNCiYUx&tracking_referrer=www.theguardian.com)), and the current conservation status by [Reis et al. (2017)](https://academic.oup.com/bioscience/article/67/6/523/3859715?login=false) shows that most of the HJBL region is unprotected, except for some Ramsar sites and some protected areas.
